name: Psychonauts
description: A Psychic Odyssey Through the Minds of Misfits, Monsters, and Madmen. This classic action/adventure platformer from acclaimed developers Double Fine Productions follows the story of a young psychic named Razputin.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 98 SE/2000/XP Processor: 1.0 GHz Pentium(R) III and AMD Athlon(tm) Memory: 256 MB of RAM Graphics: 64 MB GeForce (tm) 3 or higher or ATI(R) Radeon 8500 or higher (except GeForce 4 MX and Go series) DirectX®: version 9.0 or higher (included with game) Hard Drive: 3.75 GB minimum hard drive space Sound: DirectX&reg 9.0 or higher compatible sound card Controls: Windows-compatible keyboard and mouse
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 2000/XP Processor: 2.0 GHz Pentium(R) IV and AMD Athlon(tm) Memory: 512 MB of RAM Graphics: , 128 MB GeForce FX 5600 or higher or ATI(R) Radeon 9600 or higher DirectX®: version 9.0 or higher (included with game) Hard Drive: 6.0 GB minimum hard drive space Sound: DirectX&reg 9.0 or higher and Sound Blaster Audigy 2 series sound card Controls: Game Pad (optional)

reviews.review_text: If you think the graphics suck, then: 1) You're wrong. 2) Buy the game. 3) Obsess over the characters and plot. 4) Buy all the merch. 5) Cry until Psychonauts 2 comes out.

Psychonauts is like a book with a weird cover. It's a game worth getting into though, even if your eyes might not agree with the art design. Once I got past my nitpicking, I finally gave it the shot it so very deserved. Psychonauts is a 3D platformer meets an adventure game and honestly, I had no idea about the former. As with all platformers, you'll die plenty from falling, which is partly due to a fixed camera and partly cos you suck. Then there are a couple of areas that just aren't very forgiving, but it's nothing you can't overcome. I'd say the difficulty level is just right for this sort of game, apart from the initally daunting and almost sadistic Meat Circus.  It's funny, charming and fun to explore. Finding collectibles is made enjoyable, but you'll have to look out for a Point of No Return, otherwise you won't get 100%. The music from Milla's Dance Party is still in my head, a level that reminded me of the club mission in DmC Devil May Cry. I doubt Ninja Theory were influenced by Psychonauts, these games being such opposites, nevertheless I found it amusing.  First Double Fine/Tim Schafer game now under my belt and I'll be checking out more from them. If it weren't for the massive development budgets we have right now, we'd see more cool games like these. Games like No One Lives Forever 3, which I'm still rooting for.

There is not much to say about Psychonauts that have not already been said time and time again. It is an excellent game that is has a timeless art style combined with great characters.  Pros + Awesome art design + Great characters with superb voice acting + Fun platforming gameplay with new moves unlocking as the game progresses + Good humor throughout  Cons - The entire game was a bit too easy on the whole until the final level, where the difficulty skyrockets - Like many games in the genre, the camera isn't always your friend and might cause some frustrations  Overall a great game and gets my full recommendation!

Psychonauts is one of the most challenging platformers I've ever played. Finding and collecting secrets completely changes the game, so take the time to explore the environment and really enjoy the picture that Psychonauts paints. Overall, the experience is rewarding and you simply won't find another game quite like it.

Seriously one of the best games I have ever played.  The characters are memorable, the levels are unique and interesting, the writing is hilarious and sometimes even deep and emotional. Once I started playing this game I couldn't stop. I beat the whole thing and 100% completed all the levels in under a week. I can't even come up with a single flaw in this game, except for maybe the fact that there isn't a sequel.  Play this game. You won't regret it.
One of my absolute favorite games from when I was younger. Wish they would make a sequel.

Very fun platformer!  Graphics still hold up due to a cartoony look and every level is a different and fun experience. The writing is fantastic and has many laugh out loud moments. The game will keep you busy and interested for at least 10+ hours. My only gripes are the collecto-thon type gameplay did wear a little bit thin by the end. I have always been a big fan of games that have you collecting items, such as Banjo Kazooie, but collecting all of the items in this game is a chore, especially the holograms. Some items, such as the collectable brains, yield different story elements and are interesting. Completing the game will probably add on at least another 5-10 hours of gameplay, all be it repititive and mundane gameplay.  TL;DR Very good writing and creative level. Collecting items grows repetitive, especially if trying to attain 100%. Very good game to pick up on sale. 8/10
TL;DR

One of my favorite games! Great art, story and mechanics. All aspects of the game have aged beautifully, and it looks better than ever.  I've played it on the Playstation2, Xbox 360, and now on Steam with a synched controller. Works great with the controller, but there are some minor issues navigating the options menu. Easily solved if you have your keyboard handy. The only problem I've found is that the game frequently crashing when loading levels from fast travel locations. While inconvienent, the quick load times keep the delay to a minimum.  This is the third time I've bought this game, and I'll do it again to put this on as many systems as I own.

Psychonauts is one of those games that you overlook because of it's age. I heard nothing but good things about it but I still was not convinced. One day I decided, why not? and I never looked back... ok I looked back like 30 hours later and a few times inbetween asking myself what I'm doing with my life but that's not relevant to this review.  So first off, this is a 3d action-adventure platformer with a light, fun and whacky art direction, everything about this game gives of a facade of humorus dialogue and ridiculous characters, but the underlying tale has a much darker theme going, telling the sad story of dissapointment and faliure, manifesting in insane and unstable human-beings given the shortest straw in life, this is a story about untangeling and getting to the core issue of one's mind and finding ways to overcome those issues. This game shows empathy and heart, it's funny, selfaware and it feels like every nook and crany in this game holds some sort of meaning, it's packed with collectibles and there is always something to do, I pretty much binged this game untill I had collected everything, not something I normally find compelling but this game somehow manages to keep my monkey-mind on track and for that it's easily one of the best games I've played so far, can't wait for the second Psychonauts.
I am the Milkman, Get this game or I'll set you on fire

With the new Psychonauts game on the way, I felt I needed to make a review for the first one. Let me start off by saying that if you have not already played this game, you are missing out. It is an absolute classic from one of my favorite developers, Double Fine. (And the man behind it all: Tim Schafer)  The game itself is filled with great humor, amazing level design, eccentric characters, a villain's ridiculous plot to take over the world, and a mysterious milkman. (Play the game to see what I am talking about) The creativity of the developers is astounding and I found myself actually wanting to come back to all the levels to collect every little thing the developers put in there. All the levels have their own charm to them and the premise of the game really allows for some of the most memorable levels I have ever had the joy to play through.   And honestly, I am extremely excited now that we are finally going to get a continuation of the story in the new game they are developing. I really hope it will be good, but even if it isn't, I still think people should pick this game up and play through it. In my opinion, it is well worth the $10 asking price, but if you still don't want to pay that much, then make a note to pick it up during a sale.    Pros

There's a reason why Psychonauts is in my top 10 favorite games of all time Positives -Unique presentation -Fantastic controls -Brilliant level design  -Well written characters, I only wish some were given more spotlight, like Boyd Cooper and Sasha Nine. -An engaging story Negitives -There was a lot of noticeable pace breaks during a play though,    namely when you get to the Insane Asylum and you have to go though 4 different minds without any real story going on. Also when you are in Rasputin's mind and you have to go to the top of the tower and then all of a sudin you need to get your levitation power.   -Near the end of the game, there's no way to go back to the hub world, so if you wanted to go back and get everything to get rank 101, you'll have to start the game all over again. Overall Psychonauts is a fantastic game  9.5/10

Doing this for the badge, but a really great platformer. If you're a fan of games like Banjo Kazooie and Super Mario 64, then you might like to give Psychonauts a try. Definitely very unique in its story and characters, lot of fun to just explore and get immersed in. Double Fine did a damn good job putting together a great game. It's usually on sale a lot/part of humble indie bundle deals, so don't let the price be the reason you don't play.

This game is so much fun! Any word you can thing of, BOOM, there it is. Amazing. Think of any situation you can, and you can make it happen. Get this game. The difficulty naturally scales based on intelligence; the words you know are probably right for your skill level. Genius concept. 8.5/10

Ahh yes, back when double-fine was good you got to play a trippy game with a banjo-kazooie feel as a main character voiced by Rodney Squirrel.  While I did enjoy this game, and suggest it. 1: I suggest you have a gamepad and 2: I suggest you do better than I did. I gave up when I had to play cleanup around the camp to buy an item to help me finish the next level.

While I've only played for such a short time, I feel like there's an overwhelming amount of collectables and epic platforming in this game. Totally recommending if you're the type of person who likes to gather every single collectable when playing a game with a lot of them.

Great game because its feels like an old school nostalgic game. Also the characters are pretty likable, something that is very cool since it's becoming hard to find this type of characters in videogames. It remembered me a lot to Rayman 2, even when both games are kinda different, it made me feel the same good sensation.  Artistically the game is beautiful and imaginative, and the majority of the levels are pretty good original and well designed.  The OST is also nice, I liked to go around the camp listening to the same tune again and again. It never bored me.  It took me 21 hours to get 100%, including all achievements, so probably the average would be like 15 hours.  It plays fine on modern PCs, so don't worry for compatibility problems. Still, I remeber I had two crashes.
'And then we took a U-turn, and then we got attacked by bees.' 'And then I bent down to tie my shoe, and then we fell in a manhole and I had to reset my own arm back to the socket.' Wow, what a life.

An amazing story, very fun, lots of puzzles and bits to collect. One of my favourite games. Really great, huge variety of things to do.  The first PONR is fine and can be reversed but there is a second less well-known one that drove me mad at the end of the Meat Circus, which stops me from playing the last level again so I'm stuck super close to 100%. This enraged me as a completionist. But if you don't plan on 100%ing, play it, it's great fun.

Tim Schafer really made a masterpiece here. The characters, world, and humor make for a fun ride. The only downside is the ending teased a sequel that we've yet to hear word of. April 2015 is the 10 year anniversary of this title. Maybe we'll see something special then.

Besides that, gameplay wise it may be the most divers games I every played.  I would warmly recommend to anyone to buy this game, hide your phone and order enough food for a few days. Let me just start off with saying, that i LOVE this game. I have played it through 4 times now and i recently picked it up on steam and 100% completed the game. The story is very interesting and somewhat original. A lot of people say, that the game hasn't aged well, but the cartoony and sometimes dodgy graphics somehow appeal to me more than modern games. I do agree, that the controls are a bit akward without a contoler, but you can get used to them.   The most important aspect about this game to me is that it scratches an itch... The countles collectibles are not obligatory to collect, but the ranking sistem makes them very rewarding. The feeling that you get after collecting every figment in a level is great and you feel like you have achieved something. (figments are one of the collectible and often hard to notice 2D models that make levels look full and colorfull)  Lastly i want to talk about the music. In my oppinion it is very well made and fits in the rather bizzare world of the game very well. I was very happy when i had the chance to get the official sountracks from the Humble Bundle.  This game is a lovely little gem from the 2005 and it's well worth its price. I can't recommend this game enough.
One of my favorite games of all time! A must own for anyone, anywhere, anytime!

Everyone who as ever played this game says how great it is...And I am one one them. First, the strongest part of this game is how it is written. Every character has their own unique way of talking and even if they are just repeating the same diologue over and over you can't help but enjoy. Next, the controls....Not going to lie, I would use an Xbox controler for this, I have beaten it on the PC using the keyboard and mouse, but it is suited best for a controler.  The story is great too, it keeps evolving with a great mystery that if you didn't figure out on your own you can look back and see the little clues and hints to it.   I cannot say enough good things about this game just.... I am a house wife, I enjoy making pies

I just recently finished Psychonauts. Sadly, I did not do it well enough to have gotten all the achievements -- I'm debating a second playthrough to get those I'm missing.   Nevertheless, it's a truly fun game. Yes, it's a platformer, so you will spend some time just trying to make certain jump sequences, or hunting for a missing thing when you thought you already checked the whole level, or replaying a boss fight because the camera angles are often terrible. But yes, despite that it's funny and fun and it made me laugh out loud quite a bit at the ridiculousness of it all.  You play Raz, a young boy who has run away from the circus to join in at Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp and hopefully to become a Psychonaut -- an international mental agent. The levels are insane -- your slightly abnormal summer camp (filled with other psychic children) soon becomes an exploration of the other minds around you, in all their whacky weirdness.  Now ... back to debating whether to finish all the achievements...

Seriously people, it's a cult classic for a reason. If you're planning on buying this wait until it's on crazy sale (Bought my copy when it was going for practically 1.75$ CAN ) because around the halfway point when there's not much left to learn the game gets MAD difficult, and if you buy it for the 9.99$ current full price, you might feel like you have wasted your money.   Besides that, who honestly doesn't want to fool (Without spoiling anything) agents into thinking you're one of them? Or become Godzilla? Of hell, simply light things on fire? This game really has it all in lue of imagenation (Here's looking at you Godzilla level that took me forever). Plus you get to play as a kid from the circus that decided to run away from it (Rather than TO it as many children must have planned to do at some point in childhood before they were allowed to cross the streets by themselves... I know I did... Sat on the curb for three hours huffing that my plans had been foiled by the road, what can I say, I was -and still am- adventerous)   All in all, it's a darn good game. You'd be hard pressed to find another Tim Schafer gem like this one...   Critisizm would be that darn difficulty curve... Oh and like, four of the kids in the game are aggrivatingly annoying as ♥♥♥♥, but at least there's only one 'Escort' thing that's totally optional, but nets you some sweet, sweet arrowheads (Money in this game) if you do it (And it's simple as hell if you're quick to reassure the character that they can make it). Other than that, it's a really good game.

Stop reading this. Seriously, Stop it. See that 'BUY' button? Click it. Buy it. Now. Thats it. Enjoy, You've just taken the steps to becoming a beter gamer and human being. Ok, still not convinced? How about Pysconaughts, Meat Circus and those roofs in Waterloo withstanding, is one of the best gaming experiences EVER. Brilliant, yes brilliant, in design, levels, charcters, story, voice work. How has this not gotten a sequel, how has Pixar not approached DF for the rights, or DF seek out Pixar? Dont worry those will be just some of the questions you ponder along with how underrated is Tim Schaffer and DF?  There is a saying, especially as you grow older, they just dont make em like that anymore. Its not really the case for games however, but for Pysconughts as with other herealded classics like HL2 and Portal there never was anything like them before or has there been anything like them sense. Truly lightning in a bottle moment for the developers and magic for those who get to enjoy.

If you’re interested in children, magic, and camps surrounded by tall fences ruled by a dictator, then you are most likely a perverted Nazi. However, If you’re interested in children, magic, and camps surrounded by tall fences ruled by a dictator, then you are a completely normal person and you will enjoy this game with a passionate passion.   In this game you spend most of your time in peoples minds uncovering the lost secrets of their pasts, and while doing so you can collected a bunch of weird chalk drawings that do nothing besides destroy the OCD part of you. These chalk drawings will consume your life, soul, and bodily fluids as at first they are easy to spot giving you a false sense of accomplishment. This easy peasy mindset lasts until the last one where you have to jump across the universe upside down on one leg blindfolded with a firecracker up your butt to get it. Since it’s the last one you have to get it, you're a gamer, OCD and completion run in your veins. Every fiber in your body is saying 'go on get the last chalk drawing' but you must resist. IT IS FUTILE. You will never get that last chalk drawing just like how Pluto will never again be a planet. You know Pluto deserves it, he after all was a planet for quite a while. Then one day a bunch of stuck up scientist with their high and mighty positions decided enough was enough. Pluto had it too good for too long. I mean of course he sat on the edge of our solar system, I mean he is just a shy guy you can't take it out on him, and just because he is far away does it not mean he cannot hear us or have feelings. Right now you know his family has out casted him and he is on the verge of suicide. AND WHAT FOR? WHY? EVERYTHING WAS FINE WHEN PLUTO WAS A PLANET. OBAMA WASN'T PRESIDENT, TWINKIES WERE STILL AROUND, AND NELSON MANDELA WAS STILL ALIVE! NELSON MANDELA!!
If you play this you must be PSYCHO,NAUT.

Psychonauts is a wonderful game and my all time favourite. Yes, it has a really unfair final level, and a rather steep difficulty curve, but that doesn't matter. Because its charming. It's funny, it's fun to play, it has some of the best level design in video game history and has a charming art style that has made sure it has not dated visually in the same way many 'realistic' looking games from the same time have. The gameplay may not satisfy everyone, but I personally love how fluid it is, and the amount of customisation is just right.  This is a hilarious game, sure, with some of the sharpest wit and cleverest dialogue in anything ever. Tim Schafer and Erik Wolpaw's (of Portal and TF2 fame) script deserved all the accolades it recieved at the time, and the story itself is also fantastic. But not only is the game funny, it has a surprising and unprecedented amount of heart. Yes, it may feature characters sneezing brains out and a level where you play a Kaiju-sized version of the main character storming a city of Lungfish (which is an awesome level by the way), but it also has moments of beauty, and even tragedy. Yes, some of the tragic circumstances are handled in a comedic way, but in no way does it make them any less powerful or striking. Don't let the cartoony look and funny dialogue fool ya into thinking that's all there is. There is much more beneath the surface (not of the actual lake in the game, more the mental variety). It has a great plot, great characters (even the insignificant side characters. You can just stand there and listen to their remarkably long conversations, which I recommend you do because they're HILARIOUS), and more specifically a great main character with Raz, who is brilliantly handled. He's never too irritating, too goofy, too heroic. He's just the right quantity of everything you need in a relatble main character who you enjoy playing as. Overall, Psychonauts is a wonderful game, and although it has some flaws later down the line, all the other previously mentioned stuff (and more that I don't want to spoil) more than make up for them. And at the price it's currently at considering it's around a 15-20 hour game, it's an absolute steal.

Its a game by Tim Schafer game. If that doesn't sell you, then I guess I'll have to talk about the game.  Psychonauts is a platformer that has collectathon elements, powers, and a ranking system, as well as a large hub world. The main chunk of the game and gameplay takes place inside the minds of individuals around the psychics' camp,calling Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp.  The characters are the best part of this game. This game is amazing in every aspect, but the characters are easily the best part of it. They're quirky, they have their own permanent personalities, they have backstories told through slideshows within that person's level, they are full of life and are portrayed so well by their respective voice actors that you never get the sense that they're people in a room recording lines of dialogue, you get immersed into the world of the psychonauts and the characters slowly have their affect on you. They also teach you valuable life lessons (for instance, control over emotions and saying that you cannot lock it completely away, or you'll explode inside Sasha Nein's marksman training).   Honestly, the rest of the game works as well as any other decent 3D paltformer/collectathon, and I can't help but comparing it to Conker's Bad Fur Day, but with fewer curse words. It functions well and would otherwise not stand out, but because of its writing and its characters (and in Psychonaut's case, its art style too. CBFD looked a lot like Banjo & Kazooie). Its powers are neat and the premise is certaintly unique, but the characters really bring this game to life.  Double Fine Productions are similar to Vigil games, as many of their games are huge cult classics, that weren't huge at their release, but have over time garnered a huge following. I just hope Double Fine doesn't go the way of Vigil.  Overall, I highly recommend it to any 3D platforming fan. Its quirky, it pokes fun and its overall a blast to play. 10/10 from me, Double Fine. I cannot wait for Psychonauts 2 to come out in...2018, supposedly...I just hope its worth the wait and meets expectations

Psychonauts is a great game. Psychonauts has problems. The positives vastly outweigh the negatives.  To get my issues with it out of the way first:  - The platforming was difficult for me in parts prompting a lot of trial and error. This sounds like a small point but when the result is continuous repetition to make a single jump it gets really annoying. - Some enemies were difficult/annoying to fight. - It's sad that you can't bind your powers to more buttons, as tabbing into the menu to swap powers out was just a little too much effort. It was released on the Xbox at the same time so you can see why this was done.  Okay now onto the positives: - The story, the environments you find yourself in, the characters and the dialogue are all great. I can't stress this enough. The Steam trailer shows a range of levels of the game but it doesn't capture how excellent the dialogue and delivery is in this story where weird psychic kids go to summer camp. - The graphical style still holds up. For a game over 10 years old, it's not difficult to watch. - Collectibles matter. You level up almost exclusively through collectibles and several of them give you extra things to read/memories to watch. They're all very whimsically created and perfectly integrated into the game. - Some real thought has been put into it. Example: the main character Razputin gives a reason as to why he can't swim (that normal video game limitation). They mention it several times and justify it. Nothing is done arbitrarily, making for a very solid world. - It's a good length. Maybe 8 hours if you rush from place to place. Which you shouldn't do! Talk to as many other characters as possible, the dialogue is wonderful.  It's so close to being a game I would say young kids should definitely play (or watch being played). However there are some words I'd call 'not okay' used, and a few moments spring to mind which could be really scary for kids. The comedy gets dark at times. Make your own judgement if you're in that situation.

Inspiring since 2005. Controls are not perfect, partly due to systems density, in particular the camera and combat aiming can frustrate. But the systems complexity is one leg of the alluring and original play, the other being imaginative setup and plot, further helped by brilliant collectibles and characterization which add to immersion in the world. Excellent production values with full voice acting, crafted art design.
The last decent game Tim Schafer came up with before his head went down the gutter.

Platform games come in many shapes and sizes. There are the big-name platforming mainstays, such as Mario and Sonic, that rely on their own brand of rules and obstacles to overcome. You have the run-and-gunners, the hop-n-bops, the Metroidvanias, the collect-a-thons, those with realistic physics, the platform hells, the list goes on and on...  However, there is a rare breed of platformer that comes out every so often that defies many of the traditional sub-genre aspects and manages to be it's own unique experience.  Psychonauts is one of those games.  The story of the begins with Raz running away from home to become a Psychonaut, a kind of mixture between a secret agent and mental projectionist. He is taken in by the training camp, set into a journey that has him entering mind after bizarre mind to solve a sinister brain stealing plot.  With mental focus being the theme of the game, Raz learns many useful abilities such as levitation, telekinesis, and even seeing how others see the world. Upgrades and useful items are everywhere and the unique locals make the exploring the various mindsets to be all the more enjoyable. The humor is also some of the most well-written and goes hand-in-hand with the stylized look. One could easily picture a Nicktoon based on the game.  Infamously bombing on it's intially release, it's earned a new life as time went on. For those looking for a unique 3D platformer on the PC, this is the first stop.

A long time ago, I ready a magazine article (back when they existed) that listed Psychonauts as the best game you never played that given year. While I do not normally take too much direction from magazines or web sites I thought I would take this one recommendation and some time later (it takes time for me to get around to things) I sauntered over to the game store and found a XBox copy in their used section and picked it up. I can say now that the magazine was definately accurate in its description as a good game but was no longer accurate in saying that I had not played it.  I'm old enough to have grown up playing that classic platformers of the NES and SNES era and was always a fan of such games. When Mario 64 came out I was immediately impressed the platformers transition to 3D gaming. Psychonauts is compariable to Mario 64 in much of the basics of 3D platforming but with some evolution beyond Mario 64. First, there is an actual story to follow; second there are slightly more fleshed out characters; and third the environments have moved beyond the obvious themes (fire, ice, castle) of Mario style platformers.  The story is fun and highly comedic. It at times will play with a trope and try to switch it up; such as the child running away from the circus. The characters themselves have some interesting details and various quirks and with some of the characters you get to dive right into their mind to explore them in a little more detail even if surreal and filled with metaphors. It is these trips into a characters mind that allows the game environment to shine and be unique and evolutionary. Unfortunately, the number of minds you get to explore felt too few mainly because they were so enterataining and I so wanted more. Thankfully, there is now a Psychonauts 2 coming down the pipe.  Somewhere in this simple review I wanted to make a play on the term minefield/mindfield but just couldn't get it to work so there we have it. Psychonauts is one of my favorite games and one of the few I have actually gotten around to finishing and completing (twice even, thanks to getting it again on Steam).  (This review done under diress in order to complete the 2016 Autumn Sale badge.)

Play. This. Game.  This is one of my all time favorite games and I have bought it for multiple platforms for a damn good reason.  You are Raz, a circus runaway determined to join the elite ranks of the Psychonauts. He infiltrates a covert training camp for young psychics and must hurry to earn his merit badges before his parents arrive to pick him up.  The characters in this are all incredibly well written and rounded, and there's no feeling of forced exposition as you're quite literally infiltrating the minds of your counsellors and 'obstacles' (the only way to really describe some of the Asylum patients) so learning their backstory is more along the lines of having read someone's diary and then having them go 'oh, uhhh, yeah, I guess you know THAT about me now.'  The characters are great, the dialogue is great, the voice acting is great, the game play is really good despite the difficulty curve ramping up in a hell of a hurry toward the end.  The graphics are dated for sure, but that's easily overlooked as part of the art style.  This game may not be for everyone, but if you don't love it I hate you and we can't be friends.  9/10

I have fond memories of Banjo-Kazooie. Having heard high praise of Psychonauts and hearing it was in a similar tone and style, it seemed like a perfect fit.  But I was never drawn in by it's whimsy like a was the old N64 platformers. That's pretty big shame because that seems to be a big draw to this game. Some mechanics seem illconceived, regardless of it's age. Some levels are fine, but other are frustrating in ways that are unnecessary. These tend to be levels that rely heavily on precise platforming in ways that 3D platforming is not meant for.  What capped off my experience with Psychonauts was the Meat Circus level: three 3D platforming sections divided by escort missions. None of this is checkpointed, so failing any section will start you back at the beginning.  My frustration Psychonauts makes me wonder if a modern 3D platformer can be successful.

Yeah yeah... I don't recommend your most favorite game of all time...  This was my first time playing Psychonauts, no nostalgia filter. Some of the praise holds true. Levels are extremely creative, changing the game up slightly with each set-piece. Many characters are hilarious and unique as well, even if 60% of them have ear-bleedingly annoying voice actors. But dear god, cutscenes, boss fights (the classic 'dodge his attacks three times and then use your new ability on him' boss fights), cutscenes (yes, I know I wrote it twice), and janky PC combat controls. Platforming is awkward, especially with the wonky self-controlling camera. Some puzzles were clever but had downright esoteric solutions.  If you're looking for a classic combat platforming game, go Sly Cooper, go Jak and Daxter, go Ratchet and Clank. This game was a grind of boredom, frustration, and brief moments of funny banter.  You may now downrate my review.

Remember that time when you ate that mouldy cheese and spent the next 24 hours on a hallucinogenic mind trip? Everyone acted strange toward you and you were certain you were the only one making sense. You were stuck in your pretty little world and despite your warped perspectives you kept on giggling like a little school girl. Sure, toward the end there were the stomach aches and the hour long toilet sessions, but to this day you claim it was the happiest time of your life.  Psychonauts is that same experience but in video game form.

This game is incredibly hilarious and fun to play with each level being unique and interesting. However, there are several frustrating flaws. Cons  Psychonauts does suffer a bit from the 'use this power for one area and hardly ever use it again' syndrome. This is somewhat remedied through the hub world, where all the powers are useful.  I think the main downfall of this game is the forced platforming. There were several moments where I had to redo a jump because I would miss just slightly, which was incredibly frustrating.  I also felt there were many moments where the game was just taking too long to progress. Now, this may be due to me being terrible at the game, but at the times where I missed a jump, I would have to go through a long sequence to get back to attempt the jump, which I would end up failing again, resulting another long sequence. The final level is also incredibly frustrating. None of the parts are necessarily difficult, but when you fail, prepare to have to redo alot of stuff to get back where you were. Pros The best part about this game are the characters. Every character you meet is incredibly interesting and unique from the others. Each one has unique character developments that you can choose to find, or skip if you don't care. The game doesn't force you to listen to long dialogues about each character. Instead, you can learn about the characters at your own pace. The levels are all unique and relate to a character. Each one has it's own quirks that make it different from the others. There were very few levels that I didn't like, and the ones I didn't like were personal preferences, rather than level design.  Overall, if you are patient, and enjoy fresh and interesting characters, buy the game. If you dislike failing or hate interesting characters, this isn't the game for you.

Original but frustrating game  The game is amazingly original. It has a great story about psychics, creative sets, and funny story telling. The game feels very original because each section is unlike any other section and keeping that high level of creativity is really hard in a game. You never know whats going to be thrown at you next but its all cool and different. The game has a dark sense of humor. It seems like a game for kids but then you see some REALLY ♥♥♥♥ed up moments that make you cringe and laugh because its horror contrasted with whimsy. It creates a great atmosphere and it's halirous. The main character and the whole cast is very distinct with each character getting plenty of screen time so you can see who they are. Each time you go in someone's mind, you see the struggle which keeps them stuck in their current state and you feel sorry for them a bit.  However, the game is very frustrating. It came out in 2005 so the graphics are bad. It supports 1600x900 but you can tell the game is basically sampled up. The cutscenes are all low resolution and run at 30fps regardless of your system which is weird. The game is old so I thought I would be able to run it fine but turning on fsaa tanks it below 60. Normally it runs around 70-120 fps but looking at certain sections drops it to about 40 which is really jarring.  Certain parts of the game are utterly frusrating because you have lots of platforming where the camera doesnt zoom out properly so welcome to trying to swing to something in the middle of the air without knowing how far away it is and not knowing if you need to double jump or not. Also, the levels sometimes go from ground to the top which adds to the atmosphere but its easy to fall and if you fall, welcome to doing the whole ♥♥♥♥ing thing again. In addition to that, the boses are just figure out which two powers affects them and repeat. There is a lot of collecting and unless you obess over it, you are never going to get it all.  Despite this, the game is still really good. It's amazingly creative and funny and if you look at all the dialogue, you'll be happy

I first rented this game for the PS2 at a Blockbuster in 2005, the title 'PSYCHONAUTS' brought my attention as well as the fresh art style on the box. Looking at the back it said, 'A psychic odyssey through the minds of misfits, monsters, and madmen.'  And below that, it spewed crazy gibberish about missing brains, bacon, mental landscapes, personal demons, ... and a mission to save the world as a Psychonaut.  Whatever this box was trying to tell me, I was already hooked on wanting to play this psychic adventure. I did not expect to meet so many colorful and funny characters or see so many inventive and strange worlds. I did not expect being a psychic meant having really cool powers to use and abuse whenever. But actually being a Psychonaut means something, and this game feels like only the tip of iceburg. So when you hear excitement about PSYCHONAUTS 2, it's not just the gameplay, but the world this game has created. It has so much room to grow in wanting to get to know the characters, and so many minds to explore to REALLY get to know the characters.   There was alot of love put into this game, and everytime I come back to it I find something new and I find new ways to interact with the world. You could easily miss alot just rushing through. But rushing is fine, all the more reason to get you replaying it again and again. Heck, that's why I bought it. Twice!  Also beware the cows! Not all milk is enriched!

I mean do I have to give you a reason? This game was great when it came out years ago and is still phenomenal. Well I was dumb and should go back in time and slap myself in the face, because this game is great. Psychonauts is just what games are meant to be. Not some cookie cutter dreck you can plop out year after year. This game deserves a sequel, but it's also perfect without it. All in all it's quite a fun, comical game, but a word of warning - it is easy to get stuck on some of the puzzles, and the platforming can be very frustrating at times.

The venerable style that is Double Fine's, is one that sticks with you well after you're done playing. In Psychonauts, that style flourishes into something that inter-meshes you with your inner-child and awakens nostalgia of younger times. All of that coupled with Double Fine's trademark situational humor and you have something that entertains from start to finish. There are some hitches in the gameplay, but that is all easily glossed over by the fun experience provided by Psychonauts.

You're at a sumer camp for psychics. Each area is a level designed on the mental subsonscious of those around you. From perky hispanic disco camp counselor, to schizophrenic nephew of Napoleon Bonaparte! This game is full of imagination and wit. However, it's forgiveable because the rest of the game is extremely enjoyable and unique. The game itself encompasses alot of exploring and gathering items that you use to gain new abilities/make them stronger, but it isn't nessicary to gather every single one. The main driver in fact is learning about the characters in the game and about Raz. Though the game is presented in a cartoonish way it conveys it's stories to you in a very profound way. Psychonauts is one of my favorite games of all time. That being said, it isn't perfect- especially the PC version (controls are a little rough), but what it lacks in the control department, it more than makes up for in the story, level design, characters, and voice-acting.  Razputin Aquato is an interesting and relatable protagonist. He's a 11-12 year old psychic that's run away from his parents' circus caravan to hone his craft at Whispering Rock Summer Camp. The acrobatic skills he uses to traverse the world are animated well and accounted for perfectly by his backstory. That amount of thought and attention to detail is commendable.    Levels are creative, colorful, and completely absorbing. My favorite (and probably the favorite of many) is The Milkman Conspiracy. Waterloo World is also great and a testament to the extremely creative and varied level design of this title.   The best parts of this game truly are the details. Every NPC can be talked to actively or listened to passively and their dialog brings depth and complexity to an already rich and hilarious world.  Even if this game has all of my love, there are still some hard truths that must be told-  -This game is a treasure-hunt. Things have to be collected to gain experience and powers. Sometimes it's a straight up grind. I'm a fan of grinding. I find it cathartic. If you don't, you probably don't want to play Psychonauts. -This game has a learning wall. Not a curve. A wall. You'll play nearly the entire game and probably not have any problems with the platforming until the very last level where traversing the world becomes really, really frustrating. -The PC version is a bit buggy and its controls aren't terribly intuitive. I suggest using an Xbox controller.   All of that aside- if you're looking for a something a little off-beat and witty, with a fantastic story and characters, Psychonauts won't disappoint.

Psychonauts is, without exaggeration, a completely unique videogaming experience. I may not be the most studied or well-traveled gamer, but I defy anyone to name me a game with a psychokinetic bear, or a conspiracy regarding milkmen, or a littany of other great moments from Psychonauts that are too numerous or spoiling to list here. It's possible to play through the entire game and miss so many small moments that really reward the most dilligent of explorers.  The PC version of this game is not without its flaws. The port is really tough on the fingers, and the game takes an incredible hike in difficulty in its last stage, going from a game of mild trial and error to a terrifying frustration simulator that might force those with anger issues to spend a little bit more replacing broken mice than they might be anticipating. Whoever designed the last level of this game should be spanked. Whoever decided the first third of it should be an escort mission doubly so.  But, in spite of all that, this is a hilarious, wonderful platforming experience with a unique cast of characters that I simply haven't seen replicated anywhere else. Do yourself a favor and get this game. Pure gold.

Psychonauts takes the standard platform-game model and slaps it in the face with a lungfish. With several unique characters, crazy worlds, and the mind-boggling story, Psychonauts does everything right.  You play as Raz, a psychic who runs away from the circus and his psychic-hating dad to Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp, a millitary funded camp for training psychic kids into becoming psychic soldiers, also known as Psychonauts (With their parent's permission, of course). Things start rough as you are quickly discovered sneaking into the camp and have your dad called to pick you up, although some counselors are impressed by you, and allow you to participate in class. Do you have what it takes to earn all the merit badges and become a fully fledged Psychonaut, and discover the dark mystery behind Whispering Rock, all before your dad comes?  Along the way, you meet many unique characters with their own varying backstories and personalities, as well as their experience with their psychic abilities. You meet a head-exploder, bear wrestler, cheerlearder, clairvoyent pervert, and many more as you wander the grounds of Whispering Rock. As you progress through the day, you see the changes and interactions between the characters, leading to unexpected alliences, suicide attempts, and love.  But what really sets this game apart from the rest are the levels. The game revolves around exploring the minds of several individuals (literally), with varying goals as to what to accomplish, whether it's to learn a new ability, find deeper meaning, or curing a mentally ill individual. Each level is designed based off the characters' personalities, with the calm, powerful counselors having organized, peaceful minds, and the crazy having dangerous, physics defying minds. As well, the collectables within each mind vary depending on the character. Figments of imagination are designed to fit in with the level design, and vaults give insight to each character's backstory and trageties that shaped them. This variation really gives Psychonauts a fresh feel every level and sets it apart from other platforming games.  Overall, with this game's amazing characters, levels, and story, as well as the occasional puzzle that keeps the game challenging, I would rate this game a 9/10. The only improvement being a Psychonauts 2 to wrap up the cliffhanger (Come on Double Fine, let's fund this game)

Even now in 2014 I enjoy this game just as much as I did the first time I played it on the original xbox. Quriky characters, over the top storyline that edges up to the entertaining side of ridiculous, and classic gameplay that has fallen out of vogue in recent years because too many games tried to cram into that genre. Every few years I dust this game off and give it another run through while wishing the sequel will finally get made. Well, at least an HD remake of Grim Fandango is coming.  I'd like to address a few of the complaints I keep seeing though in case anyone is contemplating this game:  -It's unstable- I'm sorry about your computer and your inability to use a search engine, but that's hardly the game's fault. Keep in mind, this is an older game so it is recommended to play it in compatibility mode just like every other older game. I had exactly 1 crash, when a cutscene loaded, and looked up how to fix it on google instead of ranting about it being worthless. Runs just fine.  -The controls are bad- This comes most often from people trying to play using a keyboard and mouse. The game was developed for the original xbox, what do you expect? If you have any experience with this kind of game, I can't understand why you'd even want to play it with anything other than a gamepad. Although, if you are using an xbox 360 controller to play, I recommend using the PsychoPad mod to change the on screen key icons back into gamepad buttons. This was ported a while back, so the whole thing of detecting which control scheme you were using and adjusting icons accordingly hadn't caught on yet. It's not required, but it makes the experience a little more seamless.  -The story is childish- The characters are children, at a summer camp. What did you expect? Shakespeare? Of course the children are going to have a childish understanding of events and react to them in a childish manner. They're children!  -The circus is impossible- Not really. Difficult? Yes. Quite a sharp difficulty curve from the rest of the game? Yes. Impossible? No.  -It's ugly- Not a fan of art, eh? Sorry, not every game is Generic Greyish Brown Shooter With Lens Flare 7.  -Random camera complaints that differ between people- Well the fact that no one can agree on what these camera issues are makes me think this is a highly personal thing rather than an issue with the game. In later parts there are some weird camera things done for effect, such as seeing yourself from the point of view of the thing attacking you, and that can be a little disorienting for a few moments but that's not even remotely what people claim. It's a bit like someone who hates turkey ranting about the quality of a traditional thanksgiving dinner. Of course they're not going to like it, even if it's the best turkey you've ever eaten. The only other thing I can think of is maybe this is a quirk of trying to use a keyboard/mouse to play. This was a game designed for the xbox, so just use a gamepad and you'll be fine.

Where do I begin... To start off I must say, this game is just.. Fantastic! It's an old school platforms with loads of collectibles, tons of Easter eggs, and an amazing sense of crude humor. I vowed to myself not to wrote a review of this game until I completed it 100% and got every achievement, and as frustrating as that is in a lot of games, I found myself WANTING to continue to do so with this game.   You play the game as a boy named Razputin, a 10 year old boy with an affinity for psychic powers. You go to a summer camp where the staff teach the children how to harness and perfect their psychic abilities. I won't go too into detail about the plot, but basically some really crazy stuff starts going down and Raz gets to the bottom of it. The goal Raz has in mind is to become a Psychonaut, a psychic soldier.   The game play is so much fun, the story is great, the voice acting is awesome, and for a game that came out over 10 years ago, the graphics are just fantastic. The cutscenes are a little dated but otherwise, they're still fantastic and hold up very well. This game is one of the greatest platforms of all time, and anybody who likes platforming, adventuring, or both, this game is a must have. It's worth the $10 but it often goes on sale for $5 and sometimes even $0.99. It's worth every penny and more.  10/10 will play again and again.

I finally decided to give Psychonauts a try after having it sit in my Steam library for a while. I wish I had played it sooner! It’s a great “old school” (Xbox and PS2 era) 3D platformer. You play as Raz and are wanting to become a Psychonaut but have to interrupt your training to find out who is stealing the brains of the kids in the camp you’re at. The story is progressed mainly by entering the minds of various characters and going through their world. A very cool way to tell a story.  The areas and levels you go through are all very different and unique. No two areas feel the same. This is really where the game shines. You can tell some time and creativity was put into creating all of them.   The graphics and sound are quite good for an older title. Textures are sharp (sometimes stretched a bit) on most things. The cutscenes are the original low-def quality since they were not remastered. As with the unique levels, unique music is in each of them. The music seemed very fitting for each situation and environment.   Controls are sold…not the best, but solid. I would highly recommend a controller to play this. Some platforming elements (meat circus level) were made harder than I felt they should have been.  I had some issues with random crashes, but only in the beginning of the game. After that it was very solid. The game autosaves, but I made sure to manually save often when it kept crashing. Just a minor annoyance that went away after the first few hours of gameplay.   Psychonauts has several collectibles throughout the game. However, it’s not overwhelming and certainly feels doable if you put in the time.   I was disappointed to see no way to re-visit the real world after completing the game. You pass a point of no return where you can only revisit the different memory levels. Luckily, the game autosaves a spot at this point so you can go back and find anything you need before finishing the game up.   Pros  +Different and cool story +Graphics and gameplay are good and still hold up today +Collectables are not overwhelming +Different variety and style for each level +Characters fleshed out well +Unexpected humor +Music +Auto and manual saves +Powers earned are fun to use   Cons  +Platforming mechanics +Random crashes in beginning part of game +Fairly easy overall +Missable achievements   I would easily recommend this game to anyone that’s a fan of 3D platformers. It’s not a very difficult game and offers great gameplay that still stands up today.    8/10  Very good

I’d like to start off by saying that Psychonauts is a FANTASTIC game that everyone should play at least once. From the level design to the characters, it gushes personality. That being said, nothing is without flaws, Psychonauts included.     Technical:  While the level design is very strange and often wonderful, it seems to often cause conflicts in collision detection between objects. In the very first level, as you go off a platform to a tightrope, you get caught at the point they connect. While you can just jump to overcome this, it is a frequent problem that I have found throughout the game. Not game breaking, but still bothersome. Some areas of the game, specifically Meat Circus have some very unforgiving jumps not hard purposefully, but by the fact in you are on a type of time limit. Luckily, the PC version of the game was made more lenient and does not take away life or lives when a jump is failed. If not for that, I’d bet very few people would have finished the game. Altogether, I would rate the level design at 8/10.     Graphics/Level Design:  I have to applaud Double Fine for the bizarre and fantastic style the game exudes. Each level is distinct and memorable. Seeing the Milkman Conspiracy for the first time was one of the few times a game left me in awe. The colorful pallet used throughout the game matches the style of the game to a tee. My favorite level from a graphic and style standpoint has to be Black Velvetopia. The ultraviolet coloring is vivid and striking and matches well with the artistic Edgar’s brain well. My one complaint is that many of the larger textures are very low quality. My guess is that stems from this game being ported from consoles in 2005. I would have liked if they had done a once over and fixed a few textures, but it is only a momentary distraction from a wonderful game. Again, 8/10.     Characters:  Any lastly, but certainly not least, the characters! Every character seems to be fleshed out and have a backstory. I’ve read that the director Tim Schafer even created Friendster and Myspace accounts for many of the character and it shows. From Raz’s distance from his father to Milla’s ill-fated children, it was a joy getting to know each character. My only grip would be that the cut-scenes are VERY compressed and do a poor job of matching the rest of the game. Again, I assume this was a technical limitation due to the games age. Despite that, I’m giving the characters a 10/10.     In conclusion, if you are on the fence about trying out this game, GET IT. In my twenty years of gaming I would say this game is in my top ten games, maybe even number one! 9/10.

This is not your usual game. It's not a survival horror. It's not an open world. It's not a roguelike/roguelite. It doesn't have fancy graphics or a hige budget. What it does have is heart and soul. And weird. This is a game in which you go into people's minds and fix their emotional problems with psychic powers (and platforming). Every mind is different, and the rules and objectives change. You get to see into your enemies, and this, more than anything, is what makes Psychonauts so much fun. The platforming is good, the progression is engaging, and the powers are cool, but the characters are what drive this. Some of it is about how you get from here to there, butit's also about why.  More than that, it's easy to identify with the protagonist. You might think that a kid psychic who looks a bit like a bobblehead would be tough to empathize with. You'd be wrong.  Anyway, play the game. It's worth it. It's worth more than they're asking.  Graphics: old. Not amazing when released, but solid. But you're not playing this for the graphics. Sound: Voice acting is good. Kinda cheesy sometimes, but it's meant to be a bit campy. Effects are good. Gameplay: Creative, challenging without being cruel, sometimes a bit confusing (though that's part of the fun). And it will pull you in to its world, which is so dang rare. Replayability: Story is linear, but fun. There are some collectibles you could go back for, but it's more like re-watching a favorite movie. You go back not to find a new experience, but because the one you had was worth repeating.  Value: It's $10 ($1 right now!!!) so no excuses. And you can put the money you save towards THE SEQUEL THEY'RE FINALLY MAKING! Holy heck, where to even start.  I have tried on many occasions to explain psychonauts to someone who has never even heard of it, but every time I find myself struggling to find things to compare it to. This reason is why I found psychonauts so enjoyable, the fact that it is increadibly unique and interesting in a way that not many games can pull off. Its environments are trippy, bizzare and beautiful, all while harboring some of the greatest level design in any game I have ever played. Its characters are all unique and interesting, from the campers that only show up 3 or 4 times in the whole game to the main protagonist. The story is interesting and enthralling, only suffering from minor pacing problems. The humor is origional and quite funny, helping set the game apart further from most other story heavy games that rely on sadness and entropy to drive the players emotions. The only complaints I have are that the controls and camera do not handle perfectly, and have led to a number of dissapointing moments. As I mentioned before, the story and difficulty arc have pacing problems, with the game turning from easy nearly remedial practice courses to controller snappingly hard puzzels and platform sequences in a blink of an eye. If you try to rush the game and don't take time to explore and examine the camp and/or don't collect enough figments, you will find yourself stuck about halfway through the game, needing to farm for psi challenge markers/figments.   In conclusion, this game is perfect if you love story driven games with beautiful landscapes and don't care too much about control problems. In my personall opinion, I would give this game a 9/10.

It has an amusing plot about breaking into a summer camp. The dialoge is clever and amusing for NCP's. The best part is that each level is designed like a different game all within the same game. The creativity of each level makes the discovery the most entertaining part of this game. A fun game with casual elements that give this game a lot of replay value as well.
Why this game has not been played by every single person on the planet is beyond me. It should be law. Especially the Lung Fish level.  Play this , if only for Lungfishopolis.
I played this game first when I was fourteen, and then again when I was twenty two. Somehow, it was even better than I remembered. A truly one-of-a-kind gem.
One of my favorite games of all time.
Still holds up very well after all these years.

Absolutely charming game that didn't get the exposure it deserved on release. Excellent story, excellent characters, excellent pacing. You need this game in your library right now - this is the only game that I've ever gone out of my way to pick up extra copies just to gift to friends.  The only downside is that it's probably not suitable for vegetarians/vegans who are such on moral grounds.
For me one of the best game there is :D

I love this game. It's a fun platformer with an original story. Playing Raz and jumping into people's brains to collect the figments of their imaginations, clear out their mental cobwebs, and help sort out their emotionl baggage not only fuels laughs but also satisfies the 'collect all the things' urge.The writing is silly and clever. I've owned and played this game on several platforms and it's always worth it. It's 9 years old and is still fun. I will admit that the graphics are starting to get a bit dated, maybe they'll eventually release a remastered edition.
It's damn Psychonauts. It's funny. It's fun.   It's a true classic. There's gonna be a sequel eventually, too. Now's a good time to play it.
a classic, a master piece, my childhood  but make sure you run it in compatibility for windows 95.
This game is trippy, but fun.

'My Name-' -Raz 'STARTS WITH A D!' -Oleander '-Is Razputin.' -Raz 'Hmmpph.' -Oleander  Probably my favorite platformer of all time. Writers have a great sense of humor and the characters are some of the most intruiging I've seen in a while, and this was made in 2005.  Playtime: 10-18 hours (depending on if you collect all the collectibles and such)  Gameplay: Great Parkouring system and the Psychic abilities really add to the fun  Humor: Great, and bounding to make you at least smile  Difficulty: Mostly ok until end where if you don't know what you're doing it can be a bit hard.
